title: Getting Started with tidymapgrid
text: tidymapgrid package provides simple interface converting geographic polygons grid representations. particularly useful creating tile grid maps (also known grid cartograms) geographic unit represented uniformly-sized cell.

title: Getting Started with tidymapgrid
text: Traditional geographic maps can misleading : Large areas dominate visually even ’re important data Small areas hard see even contain important information Irregular shapes make difficult compare values across regions Grid maps solve problems representing geographic unit equal-sized cell, making comparisons fair easy.

title: Getting Started with tidymapgrid
text: can install tidymapgrid GitHub:

title: Getting Started with tidymapgrid
text: First, load geographic data sf object. example, ’ll use sample dataset Puerto Rico municipalities comes bundled package:
code: # Load sample data bundled with the package pueblos <- readRDS(system.file("extdata", "pueblos.RDS", package = "tidymapgrid"))  # View original map ggplot(pueblos) +   geom_sf(fill = "steelblue", color = "white") +   theme_void() +   labs(title = "Puerto Rico Municipalities (Original)")

title: Getting Started with tidymapgrid
text: get_grid() function converts polygons grid:
code: # Create hexagonal grid hex_grid <- get_grid(pueblos, type = "hexagonal", seed = 42)  ggplot(hex_grid) +   geom_sf(fill = "steelblue", color = "white") +   theme_void() +   labs(title = "Puerto Rico Municipalities (Hexagonal Grid)")

title: Getting Started with tidymapgrid
text: can also create square grids:
code: # Create square grid square_grid <- get_grid(pueblos, type = "square", seed = 42)  ggplot(square_grid) +   geom_sf(fill = "coral", color = "white") +   theme_void() +   labs(title = "Puerto Rico Municipalities (Square Grid)")

title: Getting Started with tidymapgrid
text: grid retains attributes original data, making easy create thematic maps:
code: # Add some example data hex_grid$value <- runif(nrow(hex_grid), 0, 100)  ggplot(hex_grid) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = value), color = "white") +   scale_fill_viridis_c() +   theme_void() +   labs(     title = "Thematic Grid Map",     fill = "Value"   )

title: Getting Started with tidymapgrid
text: seed parameter ensures reproducibility. seed always produce grid layout: Different seeds produce different arrangements, can experiment find pleasing layout data.
code: grid1 <- get_grid(pueblos, type = "hexagonal", seed = 123) #> old-style crs object detected; please recreate object with a recent sf::st_crs() #> old-style crs object detected; please recreate object with a recent sf::st_crs() grid2 <- get_grid(pueblos, type = "hexagonal", seed = 123) #> old-style crs object detected; please recreate object with a recent sf::st_crs() #> old-style crs object detected; please recreate object with a recent sf::st_crs()  # These are identical identical(grid1, grid2) #> [1] TRUE

title: Getting Started with tidymapgrid
text: Experiment seeds: Try different seed values find layout best preserves geographic relationships data. Choose right grid type: Hexagonal grids look organic often preferred statistical visualization Square grids simpler may work better certain applications Consider data: Grid maps work best comparing values across regions. actual geography important, traditional map may appropriate.

title: Convert Geographic Polygons to Grid Representations
text: tidymapgrid provides simple interface converting geographic polygons grid representations (hexagonal square). useful creating tile grid maps geographic unit represented uniformly-sized cell, making easier visualize data without distortion caused varying polygon sizes. package wraps geogrid package returns tidy sf objects integrate seamlessly tidyverse ggplot2.

title: Convert Geographic Polygons to Grid Representations
text: basic example shows obtain grid map.
code: library(sf) library(tidymapgrid) library(ggplot2) json_url <- 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ian-flores/Hurricane_Maria_Mortality_Analysis/master/analysis/data/pueblos.json'  pueblos <- st_read(json_url) #> Reading layer `pueblos' from data source `https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ian-flores/Hurricane_Maria_Mortality_Analysis/master/analysis/data/pueblos.json' using driver `GeoJSON' #> Simple feature collection with 78 features and 3 fields #> geometry type:  POLYGON #> dimension:      XY #> bbox:           xmin: -67.27135 ymin: 17.92688 xmax: -65.24442 ymax: 18.51576 #> CRS:            EPSG:4326  ggplot(pueblos) +   geom_sf() +   theme_void() grid <- get_grid(pueblos, type = 'hexagonal', seed = 40)  ggplot(grid) +   geom_sf() +   theme_void()
